head.title: Exploring the Intersection of Personal and Public Authorial Voice in the Works of Willa Cather | Digital Scholarship in the Humanities | Oxford Academic

div.h1: Exploring the Intersection of Personal and Public Authorial Voice in the Works of Willa Cather

div.div: Department of English, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, USA

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 30, Issue suppl_1, December 2015, Pages i36–i42, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqv041

div.p: Laura Dimmit, Gabrielle Kirilloff, Chandler Warren, James Wehrwein, Exploring the Intersection of Personal and Public Authorial Voice in the Works of Willa Cather, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 30, Issue suppl_1, December 2015, Pages i36–i42, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqv041

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: This research began in a class taught by Matthew Jockers and has continued under his direction as a project of the newly formed Nebraska Literary Lab. Our work focused on mining the fiction and non-fiction works of Willa Cather that are housed in the Willa Cather Archive at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (Jewell, Andrew. The Willa Cather Archive. University of Nebraska-Lincoln, 2004–2013. Web). Largely regarded as a private person, Cather forbade the publication of her correspondence; only recently have her letters finally been published. With the publication of these letters comes the unique opportunity for scholars to research Cather’s personal thoughts and voice. Our research focused on using stylometrics to explore the ways in which the voice Cather used in her correspondence differs from the voice she used in her public writing; our conclusions point to similarities between Cather’s novel My Mortal Enemy, a work noted for both its economy of style and autobiographical features, and her recently published letters.

div.p: Looking into an author’s unpublished writings for additional insight is an analytic strategy with a long history in literature studies. The works of the early 20th century American novelist Willa Cather offer a valuable opportunity for scholars to examine the intersection of published and private writing. Born in Virginia in 1873, Cather moved to Nebraska in 1883. After graduating from the University of Nebraska in 1895, Cather relocated to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, before moving to New York City. It was while in New York that Cather matured into the commercially and critically successful novelist who would go on to win the Pulitzer Prize in 1923. Though many of Cather’s works are strongly influenced by her personal experiences, her novels about the Nebraska prairie—for example, O Pioneers!, My Ántonia, and A Lost Lady–are especially striking in their vivid inclusion of personal details and emotional reflections from her childhood on the Great Plains.

Despite the autobiographical nature of her writing, Willa Cather has been widely regarded as a private person, in part because she carefully controlled public access to her personal writing. Because Cather forbade the publication of her letters in her will, a close examination of the correspondence has, until recently, been impossible. The recent publication of Cather’s letters, enabled by the Willa Cather Trust, offers an exciting and unique glimpse into the private life of Cather, a life that she kept carefully guarded.1 Our work seeks to capitalize on the recent publication of the letters by statistically comparing Cather’s correspondence with her works of fiction. By using the statistical programming language R to calculate frequently appearing words in Cather’s works, we were able to stylistically examine the way Cather’s voice differs in her letters and fiction.

After the selected letters were released, many readers anticipated a dramatic revelation about Cather’s personal affairs.2 Upon examination, though, no such lightning bolt appeared. Rather than offering shocking portraits of private events in Cather’s life, the letters paint an arresting portrait of Cather primarily through their candid, bold, and humorous tone. The letters are full of opinions, day-to-day occurrences, and intimate musings about writing. It is our hope that our statistical examination of the recently published letters will draw attention to Cather’s vibrant personality and open up productive avenues of inquiry for scholars interested in her personal writing. We believe that the benefits of the work we have performed on Cather’s personal voice are not limited to Cather studies. The potential applications of this type of statistical analysis in literature studies as a whole are wide reaching. Many authors have left behind extensive collections of personal writing that could hold untapped insight into how they communicated in different settings, and how their writing evolved.3

We initially expected that Cather’s personal voice would differ from the narrative voices present within her works of fiction. Scholars have found the voice that emerges from Cather’s letters to be particularly vibrant, forthright, and bold. As Andrew Jewell and Janis Stout note, the letters reveal Cather’s vivacious (and previously muted) character (Jewell and Janis, 2013). This view is supported by Cather’s own comments on her correspondence; Cather was in part anxious about the publication of her letters because she felt that they embodied a style that was not as polished as her public work. In a letter to fan and English Professor Carlton F. Wells, Cather writes: ‘I am sorry not to be able to oblige you, but I never allow quotations from personal letters to be printed. When, among a great number of the rather flat and dreary letters I receive, I come upon one that is alive and intelligent, I am rather prone to answer it in a somewhat intimate and unembarrassed tone’ (Cather, 2013).

Our close reading of the individual letters in our corpus supports Cather’s claim; in reading the letters we discovered a voice that is alive, intelligent, and unembarrassed. Consequently, our initial research questions revolved around the relationship between private and public authorship: is there a measurable, stylistic difference between Cather’s voice in her letters and in her fiction? We were also interested in determining whether or not any of the works of fiction were more similar to Cather’s private voice than others: how (if at all) did Cather’s fiction act as a mouthpiece for her personal voice? In response to these questions, our study focused on comparing Cather’s correspondence to a corpus of fifteen works that span Cather’s career in fiction.4

In the tradition of Burrows and others working in authorship attribution, we elected to measure style based on the occurrence of high-frequency word features, or function words.5 It is of course a drastic oversimplification to state that ‘style’ can be reduced to frequently used words. However, the success this approach has achieved in authorship attribution does indicate that high-frequency word features form a distinct aspect of a writer's voice. Further, the precedent set by authorship attribution indicates that these word features can be successfully used to examine the differences between authorial voices, a concept essential to our endeavor.6

Our research was divided into two main tasks, first, we established a personal voice proxy from Cather’s correspondence. The personal voice proxy served as a stylistic measurement of Cather’s voice in her letters. The proxy was created by using a mean frequency threshold to determine a set of frequently used words in the corpus of Cather’s letters. Our proxy included fifteen commonly used words that are not context specific, such as ‘in’, ‘an’, and ‘the’. We experimented with different thresholds until discovering a threshold that produced the greatest number of word features that did not contain any context specific words. For example, slightly lowering the threshold resulted in sixteen words; however, upon inspecting these words we realized that the 16th word, ‘New’, was a context specific word derived from the many addresses and references to New York City.7 Relying on high-frequency word features allowed us to both avoid arbitrarily selecting words, and to avoid relying on context-specific words.8 It is likely that the fifteen frequency features that we derived are also less dependent on an author’s conscious decision to vary her vocabulary. Function words might offer a better indication of the subconscious, intrinsic choices that inform a writer’s voice.

Our second task required us to filter the initial corpus of letters. We started with a corpus of 566 letters that spanned Cather’s life. While many of the letters were written to close family and friends, Cather also corresponded with business associates. Rather than handpick letters that we believed captured Cather’s personal voice, we opted for a more quantifiable approach to determine a group of personal letters. To do this, we performed unsupervised clustering on the letters. Unsupervised clustering is a method used to computationally group items together based on a measure of similarity, in this case Euclidean distance, which has been shown by Burrows and other to be an effective measure in stylistic analysis. The distance measure was calculated across the fifteen features extracted from each letter.9 It was our initial hope that the letters would cluster into two distinct groups: private and public. However, we found no clear demarcation between a single group of personal letters and a single group of business letters.

We continued to experiment with cluster settings, increasing the number of clusters until a cluster emerged that contained a significantly high percentage of letters written to close family members and friends. At eight branches, a cluster of 164 letters emerged.10 This cluster, from which we derived our personal voice proxy, contained a large percentage of letters written to people whom Cather was especially close to. In addition, of all of the clusters that emerged, this cluster of 164 letters contained the highest percentage of addressees to whom Cather most frequently wrote letters, a further indication of the fact that the recipients in this cluster were people with whom Cather had a close relationship (see Fig. 2).11

img.alt: Chart of statistical distance between fiction works and letters. This chart depicts the degree of difference between the use of high-frequency words in Cather’s letters and in her works of fiction. The difference is calculated using the 1,000 word chunks that each novel was broken into. A lower position on the Y-axis indicates a greater degree of similarity. The upper bar indicates the average distance, and the lower bar indicates the standard deviation

div.p: List of letter recipients in cluster 18.Names are listed as they appear in the addressee tag of the XML letter files used. Some letters were written to multiple correspondents

Once we had winnowed our corpus of Cather’s letters and derived her personal voice proxy, we compared this proxy to her fifteen book-length works of fiction (see Fig. 1). In order to accomplish this comparison, we calculated two statistical measures of similarity: Pearson’s correlation coefficient and Euclidean distance. These two units of measure compare the similarity between Cather’s personal voice signal and her use of function words in the corpus of novels. A correlation coefficient is a number between −1 and +1 calculated to represent the linear relationship, or dependence, between two variables; it measures the strength of a relationship between two sets of data. In this case, we measured the frequency of function words in Cather’s letters and works of fiction. Euclidean distance does not measure dependence; rather, it expressly examines the direct difference between two variables. Examining the Euclidean distance provided a way to calculate the numerical distance between the frequency of the function words within the personal correspondence and the frequency of the same set of function words within each of the fifteen novels.

We divided each of the works of fiction into 1,000 word chunks in order to track the extent to which portions of the works were more similar to Cather’s personal voice than others. In order to calculate a unique Euclidian distance for each work, as opposed to its parts, we averaged the distances for all the 1,000 word sections of each work to determine a mean similarity between each work and Cather’s personal voice signal. Examining both the length of individual chunks and the averages for each individual work allowed us to take into account whether or not outliers within the works were throwing off the averages. Dividing the works into measurable chunks also opens the door for future research: by examining which individual chunks of text most closely match Cather’s personal voice signal, we hope to be able to explore which characters have a voice most similar to Cather’s.

Our findings on the similarity between Cather’s personal voice signal and her use of function words within her works of fiction did reaffirm our initial impression that Cather’s voice in her letters is unique from the voice present in her fiction. Cather’s use of function words within her works of fiction was significantly different from the personal voice proxy calculated from the correspondence. However, the frequency of function words did not vary significantly among fourteen of the fifteen fictional works we examined. This would indicate that, while there is a difference between Cather’s ‘personal voice’ and fourteen of her published works of fiction, certain aspects of the voice she adopts in these works remain constant. This result is somewhat surprising given the multitude of diverse narrative voices, settings, themes, and characters that inhabit Cather’s fiction.

We were surprised to find an outlier among Cather’s works of fiction; the frequency of function words within My Mortal Enemy more closely resembles the use of frequency words in Cather’s correspondence than any of the other works examined.12 Previous scholarly commentary on Cather has also indicated that My Mortal Enemy is a singular book in her fiction corpus. It is regarded as especially economic in its use of language; Elizabeth Gates Whaley observes that ‘the method and form are so conducive to bringing out Cather's particular talents . . . she wrote her best when she used few adjectives and adverbs, when she wrote sparingly, simply’ (Whaley, 1974, pp. 124–33). The narrative structure has also been the subject of scholarly attention: My Mortal Enemy is widely considered to be the embodiment of Cather’s own novelistic ideal, the ‘novel démeublé’. For Cather, the novel démeublé was an evocative form of realism, stripped of unnecessary detail and embellishment. While My Mortal Enemy may exemplify these qualities, scholars have also pointed to other novels in Cather’s corpus that demonstrate a sparse realism indicative of Cather’s stylistic ideals, such as A Lost Lady. Thus, this alone may not be enough to explain My Mortal Enemy’s relationship to the correspondence.

The style of narration present in My Mortal Enemy raises interesting questions about similarities between this novel and Cather’s letters. If My Mortal Enemy embodies Cather’s own idealized notion of bare, to-the-point writing, then is it possible that Cather also adopted a similar style in her personal letters? Interesting questions are also raised by the way in which My Mortal Enemy draws from Cather’s life.13 Though Cather sought to keep the connections between My Mortal Enemy and her personal life private, several Cather scholars, including Emmy Stark Zitter, have pointed out the ways in which My Mortal Enemy seems to borrow heavily from Cather’s personal experiences, noting that within the novel, Cather ‘exercises the autobiographical impulse’ (Zitter, 1996, pp. 289–301).

Ultimately, our study raises more questions than it answers; while My Mortal Enemy is certainly a unique work in many respects, there is not a single identifiable reason that accounts for the novel’s similarity to Cather’s correspondence. We might assume that in writing about deeply personal issues an author is likely to lapse into a more personal style. However, scholars have pointed out the strong autobiographical tendencies in many of Cather’s works, including the many novels she wrote about her experiences living in Nebraska.14 We might ask, what specific elements of the autobiographical nature of My Mortal Enemy might indicate an unconscious use of a more personal style of writing? What makes My Mortal Enemy distinct from Cather’s other partially autobiographical novels, such as My Ántonia? In the future, we hope to continue to explore these questions further; using high-frequency word features is only one way to measure authorial voice, and broadening out personal voice proxy to include other stylistic markers, such as sentence length, syntax, and vocabulary richness, might allow us to further compare Cather’s fiction with her letters. The original goal for our research was to yield future questions for investigation, and it is our belief that the similarity between My Mortal Enemy and Cather’s correspondence leads to interesting future areas of inquiry.
This work was supported by the Center for Digital Research in the Humanities at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. XML files were provided by the Willa Cather Archive.
1 The Selected Letters of Willa Cather, published in 2013, contains 566 of the roughly 3,000 surviving Cather letters (Jewell and Janis, 2013).
2 The expectations concerning the letters were in part driven by scholarly and public speculation concerning Cather’s sexuality, which has long been the subject of scholarly inquiry and debate.
3 In addition to the Willa Cather Archive, other digital archives publishing author correspondence include the Walt Whitman Archive, the William Blake Archive, and the Mark Twain Project.

4 The works that were selected are as follows: Alexander's Bridge, O Pioneers!, My Ántonia, One of Ours, The Troll Garden, The Song of the Lark, Youth and the Bright Medusa, A Lost Lady, The Professor’s House, My Mortal Enemy, Death Comes for the Archbishop, Shadows on the Rock, Obscure Destinies, Lucy Gayheart, Sapphira and theSlave Girl. These works represent all of Cather’s book-length fiction published in her lifetime and were made available to us through the Willa Cather Archive.

5 For a further discussion of function words, please see: ‘“Delta”: a measure of stylistic difference and a guide to likely authorship’ by J. Burrows. Also see: ‘Quantitative authorship attribution: an evaluation of techniques’ by J. Grieve (2007, pp. 251–70).

6 All of the statistical research conducted as part of this project utilized the computational language R. R is an open-source statistical computing language. For more information, see: http://www.r-project.org/
7 The fifteen words used were: a, and, for, have, i, in, is it, me, my, of, that, the, to, you.

8 In their study, Jockers, Witten, and Criddle demonstrates some of the potential benefits of using function words. Please see: ‘Reassessing Authorship of the Book of Mormon Using Delta and Nearest Shrunken Centroid Classification’ by Matthew L. Jockers, Daniela M. Witten, and Craig S. Criddle.
9 For more information on unsupervised clustering and Euclidian distance, please see: ‘Textual Analysis’ by J. Burrows (2004) and Macroanalysis by Matthew L. Jockers (2013, pp. 158–60).
10 These digital letter transcriptions from the Selected Letters of Willa Cather were obtained for analytical purposes through cooperation with Andrew Jewell.
11 For a complete listing of correspondents in cluster 18, please see Addendum 2.

12 Among the fifteen works we analyzed, the average Euclidean distance was 3.97. The overall distance for My Mortal Enemy was only 2.81. The novel was Cather’s eighth book and was first published in 1926. The Euclidean distance for Death Comes for the Archbishop is also noteworthy for being higher than all the other novels, at 4.73. Though this distance is not as great as the distance between My Mortal Enemy and the rest of the corpus, this could be still be grounds for a separate scholarly endeavor.
13 For a thorough examination of the autobiographical nature of My Mortal Enemy, see ‘Unmasking Willa Cather’s “Mortal Enemy”’ by Charles Johanningsmeier (2003).

14 While the majority of Cather’s works have autobiographical elements, the novels My Ántonia, The Song of the Lark, A Lost Lady, and O Pioneers! were heavily influenced by Cather’s childhood in Nebraska.
